demographic.notes: Based on Linus Pauling Institute, peer-reviewed meta-analyses, Examine.com research, and functional medicine clinical outcomes for optimal health and longevity

protein.notes: Meta-analysis: 1.6g/kg body weight maximizes muscle protein synthesis; RDA 0.8g/kg only prevents deficiency. For 70kg person: 112g optimal vs RDA 56g. Higher protein supports muscle maintenance, metabolic rate, satiety, and healthy aging.
protein.sources: Animal proteins (complete amino acid profiles), legumes with grains

carbohydrates.notes: Focus on complex carbs from whole sources; range varies by activity level
carbohydrates.sources: Root vegetables, ancient grains, fruits, legumes

fats.notes: Evolutionary omega-6:omega-3 ratio: 1:1 to 4:1; modern Western diet: 15:1. Meta-analyses show 2-4g EPA+DHA reduces cardiovascular events, inflammation, supports brain health. Prioritize whole food sources.
fats.sources: Wild fish, pastured eggs, grass-fed meat, nuts, seeds, olives, avocados

vitaminA.notes: Retinol from animal sources preferred over beta-carotene for bioavailability
vitaminA.sources: Liver, pastured eggs, grass-fed dairy, orange vegetables (as provitamin)

vitaminD.notes: Optimal serum 25(OH)D: 40-60 ng/mL requires 4,000 IU daily (RDA 600 IU only prevents rickets). Meta-analyses show reduced risk of respiratory infections, autoimmune disease, and cancer at optimal levels. Sun exposure contributes additional vitamin D.
vitaminD.sources: Fatty fish (salmon, sardines), pastured egg yolks, mushrooms exposed to sunlight

vitaminE.notes: Mixed tocopherols from whole food sources
vitaminE.sources: Nuts, seeds, avocados, olive oil, leafy greens

vitaminK.notes: Rotterdam Study: High K2 intake (32mcg+/day) reduced cardiovascular mortality 50%. K2 activates proteins that direct calcium to bones, not arteries. MK-7 has longest half-life. Government RDAs only address K1 for clotting, ignore K2 for cardiovascular/bone health.
vitaminK.sources: K1: leafy greens; K2: grass-fed dairy, pastured eggs, natto, organ meats

vitaminC.notes: Linus Pauling Institute: 400mg for optimal health vs RDA 90mg. Supports immune function, collagen synthesis, antioxidant protection. Dose-response curve shows benefits up to 500mg from food sources.
vitaminC.sources: Citrus, berries, peppers, cruciferous vegetables, kiwi

riboflavin_B2.sources: Organ meats, eggs, dairy, mushrooms, almonds

pantothenicAcid_B5.sources: Organ meats, fish, eggs, mushrooms, avocados

pyridoxine_B6.sources: Poultry, fish, potatoes, non-citrus fruits, organ meats

biotin_B7.sources: Eggs, nuts, seeds, organ meats, fish

folate_B9.notes: Natural folate preferred over synthetic folic acid
folate_B9.sources: Leafy greens, legumes, liver, asparagus, Brussels sprouts

cobalamin_B12.sources: Meat, fish, poultry, eggs, dairy, especially organ meats

calcium.notes: Balance with magnesium, vitamin D, and K2 for absorption
calcium.sources: Dairy, sardines with bones, leafy greens, sesame seeds

magnesium.notes: 48% of US population deficient (NHANES data). Required for 300+ enzymatic reactions, ATP production, cardiovascular health. Modern agriculture depletes soil magnesium. Optimal intake 500-600mg vs RDA 420mg based on cardiovascular outcome studies.
magnesium.sources: Nuts, seeds, leafy greens, legumes, cacao, fish

potassium.notes: Crucial for blood pressure and cellular function
potassium.sources: Potatoes, avocados, bananas, fish, leafy greens, winter squash

sodium.notes: Unrefined sea salt or Himalayan salt for trace minerals

iron.notes: Heme iron from animals more bioavailable than non-heme plant sources
iron.sources: Red meat, organ meats, shellfish, legumes, spinach

zinc.notes: Critical for immune function; animal sources better absorbed
zinc.sources: Oysters, red meat, poultry, pumpkin seeds, legumes

copper.sources: Organ meats, shellfish, nuts, seeds, cacao

selenium.sources: Brazil nuts (1-2 daily sufficient), fish, organ meats, eggs

manganese.sources: Nuts, seeds, whole grains, leafy greens, tea

choline.notes: 90% of US population deficient (NHANES). Essential for neurotransmitter synthesis, cell membrane integrity, methylation, liver function. Not technically a vitamin but functionally essential. Eggs provide 147mg per egg; 3-4 eggs approach optimal intake.
choline.sources: Eggs (highest source), liver, fish, cruciferous vegetables

water.notes: Varies by activity level and climate
